subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Unicode proposal, yet again.
msgSnippet: ... I had meant to finish up the font so I could tell you I would be happy for you to use my font, but finishing it up took longer than I thought. The fonts
messageBody:
amd64_hacker wrote:
>
>
> I know that feeling.
> I've several projects I'd like to attempt with QS on computers which I'm
> holding off on until the proposal is accepted/rejected.
>
> I have to say that I'm not especially in love with the original names,
> but they are more widely known and they're also the ones listed in the
> manual.
> I don't see it as a big deal really, no one uses Unicode names in day to
> day speech anyway, so you'll still be able to use whichever name you like.
>
> I haven't submitted the proposal yet.
> One of the requirements for the proposal is outline font with a suitable
> license, I was going to ask if I could submit yours?
> I was going to just clean up QS Block's kerning and submit that, but
> yours looks nicer (IMO).
>

I had meant to finish up the font so I could tell you I would be happy
for you to use my font, but finishing it up took longer than I thought.
The fonts are actually finished. I just need some test text to show
their features.

Do you actually need to submit a font, or just images of what each
letter looks like?

You have 3 choices:

1. Use any of my svg images for the outlines. You will find the images
in the snapshot of my work at
http://quikscrit.sourceforge.net/quikscript-snapshot.tar.gz

Once you unpack the tarball, go to the alphabets directory. You will
find the directories "simple" and "calligraphy" amongst others. Choose
whatever images you want from either directory. The images are very big
and will scale nicely.

2. Use the calligraphy font I designed. I think this font displays as
you would expect at large resolutions, but I don't think it is the most
suitable for passages of text. I don't know if we want to put this font
out there as the standard.

You will find the font by unpacking the same tarball, and going to the
fonts directory. The font is Catma.ttf

3. Use the standard font I have been working hard on, which is the most
developed and fully ready for others to test. You will find it in the
fonts directory and it is called Thoth.ttf

The fonts are released under the OFL license, which allows you to use
them freely and distribute them freely. If users want to change the
shapes of my glyphs, they can do so, but they must change the name of
the font. (Or, they can let me know and we can work on improving the
font together.)

I am about to download the newest snapshot. Sourceforge has been
rejecting some of my uploads because it is busy or something else, so if
you don't see what you want in the snapshot, jsut wait a bit.

Thanks for all your work.

One reason why I want our own unicode plane is because I am working on a
word base to help me convert some text. The work base is in ASCII, where
Y is Awl, Q is out, etc. So the files are hard to read. If we had our
own plane, I could work in unicode in plane text and see what I am
doing. Plus, I wouldn't have to make two copies of each font (an ASCII
version and a Unicode version).

Paul
